question: You are a code expert, please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable whenever possible. As an experienced web developer, I need you to create a webpage that collects information about energy storage from across the internet each week, organizes it by category, and presents it on the webpage for my learning and reference. Since I work in human resources, I would also like to include knowledge related to human resources in the energy storage field. The page should be simple and clear.

checklist.title: Is the web scraping and data collection functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code includes robust web scraping mechanisms to collect energy storage information from various sources. Check if it handles different website structures, uses proper request throttling to avoid IP blocking, and implements error handling for failed requests. Score 0 if no scraping functionality exists, 5 if basic scraping is implemented but lacks robustness, and 10 if comprehensive scraping with multiple source handling is included.

checklist.title: Is the weekly information categorization system well-designed?
checklist.description: Check if the code implements a proper categorization system for energy storage information (e.g., battery technologies, grid storage, EV applications, policy updates) and specifically includes HR-related categories (e.g., job trends, salary benchmarks, required skills). Assess if the categorization is dynamic or static, and whether it can adapt to changing content patterns. Deduct 3 points if the categories are hardcoded without flexibility, and 5 points if HR-specific categories are missing. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the data storage and update mechanism efficient?
checklist.description: Review how the collected information is stored and updated weekly. Check if the solution uses an appropriate database or storage method (localStorage, IndexedDB, or server-side database), implements data versioning, and has mechanisms to prevent duplicate entries. Assess whether the update process is automated or manual. Deduct 5 points if there's no persistence mechanism, and 3 points if the weekly update process requires manual intervention. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the user interface presentation clear, simple, and effective?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the webpage has a clean, minimalist design as requested, with clear navigation, readable typography, and logical information hierarchy. Check if the HR-specific information is visually distinguished from other energy storage categories. Deduct 3 points for cluttered layouts, 5 points for poor readability (small fonts, low contrast), and 5 points for overly complex navigation structures. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as network failures during scraping, malformed data from sources, browser compatibility issues) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-powered summary of weekly trends 2. Visualization of energy storage market data 3. Personalized content recommendations based on reading history). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple sorting mechanisms that do the same thing) 2. Function modules unrelated to energy storage information (e.g., a built-in game) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary animations that slow page loading). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data fetching/processing/presentation layers), code readability, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if there's no error logging or debugging mechanism. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size ≥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Click feedback delay ≤ 100ms 2) Transition animation duration controlled between 300-500ms 3) Clear visual focus guidance. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for visual after-images during fast scrolling through weekly information, and 5 points for hard-to-find filtering or search functions. The full score is 10 points.
